subtitle: What’s happening to my body?
title: Teen Zone!
content:
Your body is growing and developing all the time. When you get to about 10 years old, you’ll notice that your body starts to change in a different way. You’ll start to grow breasts, genital hair (pubic hair) underarm hair, you’ll get taller, your hips will get wider, you’ll start to sweat more and you may get pimples on your face. 
These are your teenage years and what you’re going through is called puberty. It’ll continue until you’re about 16 years old as you change from a girl into a woman. 

**So what’s causing all these changes?** 
Your body starts to produce new hormones (chemicals) when you hit puberty. The hormones are responsible for all your physical changes, but they’re working on your emotions too. You may feel moody, sensitive, insecure, irritable or even sad. It’s your body’s way of dealing with all the changes you’re going through. Sometimes it’s good to have an adult that you can talk to.
I’m bleeding too!

Puberty is a lot to deal with and you’ll also start your period (menstrual cycle), when you bleed from your vagina. Once you get your period, it’ll happen every month for a few days. You will need to wear something in your panties to catch the blood and avoid staining your clothes. Getting your period is the sign that you could now fall pregnant if you have unprotected sex. 
Always remember that every girl develops in a different way and you are all unique! Don’t worry if you’re not growing breasts yet or haven’t got your period yet - it will happen!   

**Puberty can be a confusing and emotional time. There are no rules as to how your body will change into womanhood. Don’t compare yourself to your friends. All the changes will happen at the right time!**
